item.title: ISIS Leaders Reported Killed in Drone Strike in Afghanistan
item.description: Among those killed in the American attack in Nangarhar Province were two senior Pakistani militants who had allied themselves with the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: E.U. Official Urges Greece and Creditors to Make Concessions
item.description: The president of the European Council said there was scope for an agreement if Athens made “concrete” proposals and if creditors eased the debt burden.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Another Flag Spurs Controversy, This Time in Spain
item.description: A Basque flag flying for the first time at Pamplona’s city hall during this week’s running of the bulls has raised political tensions.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Revelers waved Basque flags alongside traditional red scarves to celebrate the start of the San Fermin festival in Pamplona, Spain, on Monday.

item.title: Pope Francis Faces a Latin America Where Many Catholics Worship to a Different Beat
item.description: Trying to breathe life in the church, Pope Francis has embraced the charismatic movement, whose Masses feature rock music, arms held skyward and faith healing testimonials.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Ivan Kashinsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congregants praying as a band played at a gathering of Catholic charismatics in Quito, Ecuador, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Says 2 Citizens Are Being Held in Gaza
item.description: The authorities said one of the captives was an Israeli of Ethiopian descent who “independently” crossed into Gaza in September and had been detained by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The mother of Avraham Mengistu, who is said to be held in Gaza by Hamas, before a news conference in Ashkelon, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Conservationists in China Seek to Get Firefly Parks Closed
item.description: In recent years, a number of commercial enterprises have tried to tap into the country’s growing nostalgia for the pulsating flickers. But environmental groups are racing to catch up.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Fireflies near Wuhan, Hubei Province. On Thursday, Shanghai's first firefly exhibit canceled its opening over safety issues.

item.title: Greece’s Economy Faces a Difficult Aftermath, Deal or No Deal
item.description: As a Sunday deadline nears for an agreement with the other eurozone nations, the only sure thing is that Greece’s economy is teetering on collapse.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nut and herbs stall in Athens. Five years of economic crisis have already taken their toll on Greece, hollowing out the solid middle class and causing tens of thousands of small and midsize businesses to close their doors.

item.title: Euro, Envisioned as Force for Unity, Becomes Weapon in Greek Crisis
item.description: The prospect of a country leaving the currency was once unthinkable, but in many ways the two sides in the Greek debt crisis have seized upon that possibility to advance their cause.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nut and herbs seller in a market in central Athens.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What You Need to Know About China’s Draft Cybersecurity Law
item.description: China, which has some of the world’s tightest Internet restrictions, has released a draft of a bill that authorizes broad powers to control the flow of online information.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Surveillance cameras in Tiananmen Square, Beijing. The release of draft legislation on cybersecurity in China followed the recent passage of a law on national security.

item.title: Chuck Blazer, Ex-FIFA Official, Is Banned for Life From Soccer
item.description: Testimony by Mr. Blazer, who pleaded guilty to widespread corruption charges in the United States, helped lead to the indictment of more than a dozen other officials in the sport.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Iran’s Unserious Critics
item.description: A good nuclear deal was made in 2013; a still better one can be had now.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘The Autobots’ Hits Theaters, and Many Chinese Say They’ve Seen It Before
item.description: One of the country’s newest movies has drawn criticism for bearing a more-than-uncanny resemblance to Disney-Pixar’s hit franchise “Cars.”
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Replicas of two characters from the Disney film "Cars" at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Talks Resume as White House Hopes for Deal
item.description: The negotiations followed a video conference on Wednesday in which President Obama issued instructions on completing an accord “that meets our requirements,” the White House said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Chinese Stocks Rise, but Fears Persist
item.description: Analysts warned that markets have further to fall, with the valuations of many small companies remaining too high.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: Stocks in China rose on Thursday after a series of government measures appeared to have their intended effect.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Germany’s Failure of Vision
item.description: The European project rejects the consolidation of power in one country’s hands. Does Angela Merkel understand that?
item.dc:creator: BRUCE ACKERMAN

item.title: Number of Syrian Refugees Climbs to More Than 4 Million
item.description: As Syria’s war drags on, families are being forced by deepening poverty and hardship to resort to more desperate survival strategies, including marrying off their young children or forcing them to work, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Study Finds Low Incomes Constrain Half of World
item.description: “Even those newly minted as middle class enjoy a standard of living that is modest by Western norms,” the report pointed out.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Plunge in Chinese Stocks Leads to Bull Market for Gallows Humor
item.description: On social media the market routs and fumbling government efforts to stop them have triggered an explosion of jokes, as Chinese investors try to find ways to ease the pain.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Investors discussing stock prices at a trading firm in Hangzhou on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: General Election Is Scheduled for Nov. 8
item.description: The military, which had ruled the country since 1964, scheduled the last general election in 2010 under rules widely seen as rigging the outcome.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Srebrenica Massacre, After 20 Years, Still Casts a Long Shadow in Bosnia
item.description: Remains are still being unearthed from the killing of about 8,000 men and boys in 1995 in the worst atrocity committed in Europe since World War II.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: The Srebrenica-Potocari Memorial in Bosnia on Wednesday. On Saturday, 136 newly identified bodies will be buried; about 1,000 victims remain unidentified.
